The GPS equation include many correction to compensate for known factors. For example, when flying near Everest, the GPS satellites are pulled down temporarily by the higher gravity field at that location. Similarly, the bulge at the equator makes gravity stronger. If we would look at time lapse, every GPS satellites crossing equator would be seen lowering altitude so many feet, then restoring altitude.

Evaluating the elevation is notoriously imprecise. The apps which succeed to compute it actually use a reference table based on map. But elevation need to be known to compensate for delay, for precise triangulation.

Another nightmare in GPS design is the echo of buildings and mountain. This is the biggest source of mistake actually. The radio wave arrive slightly later when it bounced on a tall building before reacing the GPS device.

trilateration is the process of determining absolute or relative locations of points by measurement of distances, using the geometry of circles, spheres or triangles. In addition to its interest as a geometric problem, trilateration does have practical applications in surveying and navigation, including global positioning systems (GPS). In contrast to triangulation it does not involve the measurement of angles.

Every clock, be it mechanical, be it digital, measures intervals between certain repeating events. digital clocks have several ways of measuring intervals, for example, most common clock measure the vibrations of a quartz crystal. @XXDANIEL1993XX neither special nor general relativity say anything about clocks. They both do in fact state those things about time itself. Clocks are not influenced in any way directly. But because clocks measure intervals of time, if time passes faster in one place, the intervals the clock measure are smaller, hence the clock goes faster. Keep in mind though, that these differences are only seen by an observer that is in a place time runs slower.

Time does not exist. "Time" is a concept invented by people to describe the relative position of matter over a period of "time." Time does not actually slow down in gravity; Just like the atoms in atomic clocks, matter slows down in gravity. Atomic clocks measure the frequency of atomic vibrations which we then interpret as time. the farther away from Earth's gravity the atoms get, the faster they vibrate, and the faster "time" moves.

@quedin2u It's known as gravitational time dilation. This states that the lower the gravitational potential, the slower time will pass. aka. The greater a gravitational force the slower time will pass. The equivalence principle says gravitational "force" as experienced locally while standing on a massive body (such as the Earth) is actually the same as the pseudo-force experienced by an observer in a non-inertial (accelerating) frame of reference. so it has something to do with force experienced
